TopicTitle: What is this weird paint job NASA uses on rockets?

Articles.Content:
So I'm wondering about this paint job:

What is it called? Does it even have a name? I've seen it on a lot of launch vehicles, particularly test ones. Is it a test pattern?

Edited November 1, 2014 by SpaceLaunchSystem
what else has it been used on?
It gives a reliable, easily seen, and known reference to tell what the rocket is doing in terms of pitch, roll, and yaw when you go through the imagery frame by frame.
They're called roll stripes, generally. They help identify if the rocket has any small errors in its roll attitude, by looking at footage taken of the vehicle after launch.

I can't remember what it is called, but they have something like a modern version of this on the space station.

They have black circular spots painted on the station's modules.

It's a type of video motion capture system. With the help of a computer program and cameras, they can move a module or supply craft around the station and know its precise location relative to the station.

what else has it been used on?

Well, the ares 1-x for one thing.
The stripes and checker patterns are to allow visual monitoring of roll.

I read somewhere that while Von Braun was a teenager, there was a film about a moon landing, and the rocket in the film was painted black and white. Strange, that the real moon rocket was also black and white...

Just a theory, but this is coming from a real, non-wikipedia book
